headline: Man Utd fans react as adidas unveil new home kit influenced by Old Trafford
body: Manchester United fans have hailed their new 2025-26 home kit as "a classic already" and hope it will see the team's fortunes reversed after a difficult campaign in 2024-25.
The Red Devils could only finish 15th in the Premier League after a turbulent season under both Erik ten Hag and successor Ruben Amorim, losing a total of 18 matches.

United also suffered heartache in the Europa League final as they were beaten 1-0 by Tottenham, meaning they missed out on Champions League football next season - but the team will be hopeful they can turn over a new leaf under Amorim in their new strip.
The Adidas shirt is influenced by their iconic Old Trafford stadium, with an "abstract sleeve graphic" symbolising elements of the pitch, stands and tunnel.
There is a V-neck collar laced with black edges and a white stripe going through the middle - and the same detail is seen on the edges of the sleeves.
The kit also has black stripes running down the shoulders and the words "Theatre of Dreams" on the back of the shirt.

Fans have been left impressed by the design, as one said: "A bold, clean and burning red [kit] that screams power, pride and a new era! Eager to see the away kit." Another said: "Forever red. This one's a classic already," while a third added: "I really like this, simple but with just enough flair."
Another wrote: "Excited to see the new home kit honouring Old Trafford. Looking forward to the new season with adidas."
Adidas chief Juergen Rank said they wanted to design a shirt that paid tribute to the club's DNA, playing on their iconic red colours.

"The colour red is fundamental to the club’s DNA. There have been many different expressions of it over the years and for this season we wanted to do something a little different, using the sleeves as a canvas.
"The abstract graphic stays true to the club’s DNA while providing an innovative look at feel to an otherwise classy and classic jersey."
The shirt is available to buy on Manchester United's official website and will cost £85. For the 'authentic' version of the jersey, the price is £120.
Manchester United have launched their new home kit for the 2025/26 season with an Adidas shirt paying tribute to Old Trafford.
Fans can order their Men's, Women's and Kid's shirt today.

headline: RAILSTON: Cunha just proved popular theory about Manchester United wrong
body: On Thursday, Manchester United officially confirmed their first signing of the summer.
United announced an agreement to sign Matheus Cunha from Wolves for £62.5million on the opening day of the window, but the player's visa needed to be approved before the deal could be sealed.
The red tape has now been lifted and the transfer has been formally completed. Cunha has signed a five-year contract and is the first new face through the door at Carrington this summer.
“It is hard to put into words my feelings about becoming a Manchester United player," Cunha said.

"Ever since I was a child in Brazil watching Premier League games on TV at my grandmother’s house, United was my favourite English team and I dreamed of wearing the red shirt. I want to thank my family and everyone who has helped me make that dream a reality.

“I can’t wait for the start of pre-season to get to know my teammates and prepare for the season ahead. All my focus is now on working hard to become a valuable part of the team, and helping get this club back to the top.”
If you take Cunha's comments about following United when he was a boy at face value, it shows why United will always appeal to transfer targets, regardless of the situation on the pitch.
The supporters of Premier League rivals suggested United would have no pull in the summer transfer window, but top players will always want to represent the biggest club in England.

Cunha received interest from other Premier League sides, but the Brazilian only entertained a move to Old Trafford. It still means something to play for United, which can be forgotten particularly after a nightmare season.
The 26-year-old looked delighted in his unveiling pictures on Thursday afternoon and hasn't stopped posting about United on his social media pages. He is thrilled to have signed.

Cunha didn't waste any time in posting a photo of his son in a United shirt, and his behaviour since the initial announcement of the transfer backs up his claim of "dreaming" about playing for the club.
Bryan Mbeumo has also expressed that he prefers a move to United this summer, despite interest from Arsenal, Tottenham and Newcastle, who are all more attractive on paper.
Arsenal are Premier League title challengers, Tottenham beat United in the Europa League final and Newcastle have Champions League football, but Mbeumo prefers United.

The Reds have just suffered the worst season in the club's modern history. They finished 15th in the Premier League and there is no European football at Old Trafford next season. However, United are still one of the biggest clubs in the world and that alone is sometimes enough to help attract top new signings.

headline: Man United have decided on their next four signings after sealing £62.5m Matheus Cunha transfer
body: Manchester United finalised their first signing of the summer on Thursday after announcing the arrival of Matheus Cunha from Wolves.
On June 1 United confirmed they had reached an agreement with their Premier League counterparts to sign the Brazilian international subject to a visa and registration.
The deal has now formally gone through and Cunha has signed a five-year deal at Old Trafford. United have the option to extend his stay by a further 12 months.

Cunha has become the club's first signing of the off-season after United triggered his £62.5million release clause. He was a leading target and director of football Jason Wilcox has described him "as one of the most exciting and productive forwards in England".

Cunha will add goals and athleticism to United's attack, meaning he ticks a variety of boxes for head coach Ruben Amorim. He scored 17 goals across all competitions in 2024/25, including 15 in the Premier League.

Despite strengthening their attacking pool with the addition of the former Atletico Madrid forward, United do not want their attacking additions to stop there, with Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo next on their hit list.

United, just over 24 hours after announcing they had reached an agreement to sign Cunha, discovered Mbeumo had chosen Old Trafford as his preferred destination this summer. United made an opening offer for the Cameroonian last week, understood to be worth £55m, but it was rejected.

Nevertheless, discussions between United and the Bees have remained ongoing and the Old Trafford outfit are confident of making a breakthrough in negotiations in order to make Mbeumo their second signing of the summer. United would like to get the deal wrapped up in time for the former Troyes man to report to Carrington for pre-season training at the start of July.

In addition to wanting Mbeumo, United remain hungry to sign a striker this summer. Liam Delap was United's top target to bolster their No.9 options, but they were beaten to his signature by Chelsea, meaning they are now looking elsewhere for a goal-getter.

They have been linked with a collection of strikers in recent weeks, including Sporting Lisbon star Viktor Gyokeres and Victor Osimhen of Napoli. Gyokeres is keen to leave Sporting and Napoli want to sell Osimhen.

United are in desperate need of a proven goalscorer, meaning either Gyokeres or Osimhen would fit the bill. However, amid the fact they have signed Cunha for £62.5m and could end up paying around £60m for Mbeumo, outgoings will be required to fund the addition of a striker.

As well as bolstering their attack, United also want to sign a midfielder. Christian Eriksen will be leaving the club when his contract expires later this month and uncertainty continues to surround the futures of both Kobbie Mainoo and Casemiro.
The Brazilian international is about to enter the final year of his contract and could be offloaded following United's failure to qualify for Europe next season.
United also have aspirations of signing a goalkeeper amid doubts about Altay Bayindir's future at the club. Amorim wants a shot-stopper who can challenge Andre Onana for the No.1 spot.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United suffer financial blow ahead of 2025/26 season
body: Marriott International's sponsorship agreement with Manchester United has ended.
United have been sponsored by Marriott International since 2019, but the world's largest hotel company has decided not to extend its sponsorship agreement after its contract expired.
Marriott International are cutting company-wide costs and opted against extending their deal.
Club sources have said they are "proud of their successful partnership with Marriott", and they insist United continue to have the most attractive portfolio of partnerships in football.

Last November, Marriott International announced a radical cost-saving programme, although the hotel chain agreed a new deal with the Football Association (FA) in April and still sponsors the Mercedes F1 team.
Marriott International allowed members to redeem loyalty points for United-related experiences and ran a competition to win an overnight stay in a specialist hotel suite at Old Trafford.
Andrew Watson, the vice-president of marketing for Marriott International, has said the sponsorship of the Mercedes team is one of the most successful in its sponsorship portfolio.

“Being able to tell and amplify the travel story through the lens of F1, where there are 24 global races across five continents, gives us new ways to connect with these sports fans and educate them on the value of Marriott Bonvoy," said Watson in an interview with SportBusiness.
United recently released their financial results for the first three months of 2025, which revealed a more encouraging picture after concerning comments from Sir Jim Ratcliffe about finances.

"The club remains committed to, and in compliance with, both the Premier League’s Profit and Sustainability Rules and UEFA’s Financial Fair Play Regulations," they said in a statement accompanying the results.

The positive results have seen the club increase their expected revenue for the financial year ending June 2025 to £660million to £670million, which would be a return to the levels they were posting before the Covid-19 pandemic put a hole in the balance sheet.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United lose training kit sponsorship worth £24m per year
body: Manchester United's training kit sponsorship deal with Tezos is ending this month.
Blockchain company Tezos struck a deal worth around £24million a year to sponsor United's training kit in 2022, but the contract is ending and another sponsor will be found.
Club sources are confident that a new training kit sponsor will be agreed once Tezos' sponsorship ends. There is thought to be a "strong pipeline" of potential replacements.
The Tezos-branded training kit has been worn by United's first-team squad across the last three years, and the logo has also featured on training kit worn by the women's team.
Matheus Cunha was pictured in a Tezos-sponsored hoodie in unveiling pictures on Thursday.
Tezos replaced AON as the club's training kit sponsor when they struck their deal in 2022.
The news of Tezos' sponsorship agreement ending comes after it emerged Marriott International would not be extending its sponsorship deal after its contract expired.
United have been sponsored by Marriott International since 2019, but the world's largest hotel company has decided not to extend its sponsorship agreement.
Marriott International are cutting company-wide costs and opted against extending their deal.
Club sources have said they are "proud of their successful partnership with Marriott", and they insist United continue to have the most attractive portfolio of partnerships in football.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE: Ekitike 'race', Gyokeres 'move', Osimhen 'option'
body: Even though the transfer window is closed until Monday, 16 June, the club have announced the signing of Matheus Cunha. It comes a week and a half after confirming they had reached an agreement with Wolverhampton Wanderers.

Bryan Mbeumo is another attacker on their list, having an opening offer understood to be worth £55million rejected by Brentford. United also continue to assess options up front, having missed out on Liam Delap to Premier League rivals Chelsea.

There also remains speculation about the futures of Antony, Jadon Sancho and Marcus Rashford following their loans last season. Bruno Fernandes, meanwhile, ended rumours regarding his time at Old Trafford by turning down a lucrative move to Saudi Arabia.
Follow the latest United transfer news:
According to reports in Lisbon, relayed by The Mirror, Gyokeres is thought to be ready to go on strike to try and earn a move away from Sporting.
Gyokeres' camp continue to suggest that they hold a gentleman's agreement to allow their striker to leave for less than his £85m release clause.
Sporting meanwhile are adamant that no such agreement exists and that they expect to receive his full release clause before allowing him to depart.
Viktor Gyokeres stirred the pot further surrounding his potential exit from Sporting this summer.
Posting on his Instagram story on Thursday, the striker explained:
There is a lot of talk at the moment, most of it is false. I will speak when the time is right.
The post came amid claims that Sporting have raised their asking price for Gyokeres to £68m this summer.
United signing Hugo Ekitike ahead of Chelsea and Liverpool this summer transfer window would move Ruben Amorim closer to having a completely new-look front line next season.

Matheus Cunha, after completing a transfer from Wolverhampton Wanderers on Thursday, confirmed the first step of that overhaul. United director of football Jason Wilcox describes the Brazil international as "one of the most exciting and productive forwards in England".
He "proved his ability to succeed in the Premier League" at Wolves, notably at Old Trafford in April. However, he is not a centre-forward, playing best as a second striker behind a focal point.
MORE HERE.
MEN Sport understands that Mbeumo is still giving priority to United ahead of fresh negotiations next week when the transfer window reopens.

The forward has been United's top priority since missing out on Delap and they have received reassurances that the player wants to move to Old Trafford despite the lack of Champions League football next season.
On Thursday, Tottenham confirmed that Thomas Frank would be their new manager replacing Ange Postecoglou in north London.

It is claimed that now his former manager is at Spurs, Mbeumo is more inclined to accept an offer from the club and the Europa League holders have launched an initial enquiry as to the costs associated with the deal.
Unfortunately for United, if they were thinking they would be able to sign Hugo Ekitike on the cheap they would be very much mistaken.
Eintracht Frankfurt's CEO Markus Krosche has insisted that they will demand £85m from United before agreeing to him leaving the club.
If the price isn't right, then he'll just stay with us. We don't have to sell Hugo.
Welcome back to the United transfer blog this Friday afternoon.
My name is Jack Flintham and I shall be taking over from Matt this lunchtime up until 5pm as we bring you all the updates on the Reds' transfer business.
We are going to kick things off by discussing the latest surrounding the potential purchase of this man...
Manchester United will reportedly have the opportunity to sign Dusan Vlahovic this summer.

GiveMeSport claims the Juventus striker is keen to play in the Premier League, with United said to be in the player's sights. Intermediaries and his representatives are seeking a move for the player deemed surplus to Turin's requirements.
United could reportedly extend the contract of Jadon Sancho this summer if they have to settle for loaning the player out again.

Football Insider claims they could trigger an extension to include an obligation to buy in any loan deal for the winger. Sancho's contract expires next summer, so no club would agree to such an arrangement when they could agree a free transfer instead.
Emiliano Martinez is reportedly 'waiting for Manchester United' despite receiving an offer from Galatasaray.

BOLAVIP claims the Turkish club have contacted Aston Villa and opened talks for the goalkeeper to become their new number one, replacing the departing Fernando Muslera. Martinez is said to want Champions League football next season, which Galatasaray offers as league champions, but the Argentina international also seemingly wants to stay in the Premier League.
United are allegedly his main option; however, the club are reputedly holding off as they have yet to sell Andre Onana. Villa are said to value Martinez at £30-40million.
Alan Shearer believes United signing Viktor Gyokeres would not be a surprise because of the Ruben Amorim factor.
Speaking to Betfair, he said:
On Viktor Gyokeres, I’m not surprised at all if they get him because of his work with Sporting and Ruben Amorim before, I think that was always going to be the case.

They’re not in Europe this year, they’re not in the Champions League and they’re going to have to pay huge wages to get the players and tempt them away from other clubs that are going to be interested in them.”
Rio Ferdinand would prefer United to sign Victor Osimhen over Viktor Gyokeres this summer.
Ferdinand told the Mirror:
I think Gyokeres, everyone's talking about him. Again, I think if I'm looking at the market now and I had to pick him or Osimhen, I'd probably pick Osimhen because of that experience.
And he's shown he's done it in multiple leagues now. And he's done it internationally as well. I think he's a top-class number nine who, again, the young players will be able to learn from.
I'm not saying that Gyokeres would fail. I'm just saying that if I had a preference, I would go there.
More from Ferdinand: United told to snub Viktor Gyokeres in favour of 'obvious' signing

Cunha will add goals and athleticism to United's attack, meaning he ticks a variety of boxes for head coach Ruben Amorim. Despite strengthening their attacking pool with the addition of the former Atletico Madrid forward, United do not want their attacking additions to stop there, with Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo next on their hit list.

In addition to wanting Mbeumo, United remain hungry to sign a striker this summer. Liam Delap was United's top target to bolster their No.9 options, but they were beaten to his signature by Chelsea, meaning they are now looking elsewhere for a goal-getter.

They have been linked with a collection of strikers in recent weeks, including Sporting Lisbon star Viktor Gyokeres and Victor Osimhen of Napoli. Gyokeres is keen to leave Sporting and Napoli want to sell Osimhen.
More: United have decided on their next four signings after sealing Cunha transfer
United are reportedly monitoring the potential availability of Douglas Luiz.

GiveMeSport claims Juventus are open to selling the midfielder for a cut-price fee this summer and take a loss on the £42million they paid Aston Villa last year. It is said offers as low as £30million could be enough to get a deal done.
Leeds United, Nottingham Forest and Villa are also reputedly in the race for the Brazil international. Tottenham Hotspur, though, are purportedly not.
United are preparing to announce the signing of Enzo Kana-Biyik on a free transfer.

The club are expected to formally announce the arrival of Kana-Biyik from Le Havre, unlike the signing of Harley Emsden-James - who has just turned 16 - from Southampton. Ineos-owned FC Lausanne-Sport have been linked with an immediate loan move, but it is understood that no loan plan has been confirmed.
Read more about Kana-Biyik: United set to announce signing of French striker on free transfer
United are reportedly ready to make an official offer for Viktor Gyokeres.

Maisfutebol claims that their bid would be worth £60million in total, with around £51million guaranteed and another £9million in add-ons. That, though, is said to be less than Sporting CP president Frederico Varandas wants.
United have also allegedly 'encountered obstacles' during their negotiations with Gyokeres. The striker is still reputedly on their radar, though.
Victor Osimhen remains a real option for the Reds, according to claims by United in Focus.
“We’ve known about United and Osimhen for months, and it is genuine interest," claims reporter Graeme Bailey.
United have known his wage demands and that he is prioritising a move to England for months; he has always wanted a Premier League move.

“I understand after talking with a source close to the player that we can confirm Osimhen is not basing his decision on money, if he were, he would have accepted the Saudi offer. He does, however, believe he is one of the best strikers in world football and wants to be paid as such, which doesn’t mean he will be demanding Saudi money from United.
“He knows United are an option and he wants to come to England. Chelsea is not an option; however, I am told not to rule out Liverpool.

“While not being concerned about Champions League football, he is not going to want to come and never play Champions League. United will have sold him the project with Bruno Fernandes staying, Cunha and Mbeumo joining.”
Manchester United-linked Viktor Gyokeres has broken his silence on social media as speculation surrounding his future at Sporting intensifies.
Read what he had to say here
Tottenham Hotspur have confirmed that former Reds coach Andreas Georgson has joined Thomas Frank's new backroom staff at Spurs.
Georgson, who left United this year, is a set-piece coach who has worked with Frank previously before moving on to Arsenal and then the Reds.
Manchester United have officially announced the signing of Matheus Cunha from Wolves on Thursday afternoon.
Reacting to his move, Cunha said: “It is hard to put into words my feelings about becoming a Manchester United player.

"Ever since I was a child in Brazil watching Premier League games on TV at my grandmother’s house, United was my favourite English team and I dreamed of wearing the red shirt. I want to thank my family and everyone who has helped me make that dream a reality.

“I can’t wait for the start of pre-season to get to know my teammates and prepare for the season ahead. All my focus is now on working hard to become a valuable part of the team, and helping get this club back to the top.”
Arsenal have reportedly made a formal offer for Manchester United-linked Viktor Gyokeres.

The Swedish international has risen to prominence as one of Europe's leading strikers in recent years, boasting an impressive tally of 97 goals in 102 matches since his move from Coventry City to Liga Portugal in July 2023.

Sporting's top goal scorer this season has made a significant impact in the Portuguese top-tier, netting 39 goals and providing eight assists in 33 appearances. The 27-year-old has been a pivotal player in Rui Borges' squad, driving Sporting to another league title and cup victory.
Read more here
Viktor Gyokeres has posted a message on his Instagram stories amid transfer speculation linking him with a move to Manchester United and Arsenal among others.
“There’s a lot of talk at the moment, most of it is false”, he said. “I will speak when the time is right”.
Spanish publication Marca claim that Marcus Rashford could take a considerable pay cut to accommodate Barcelona's financial situation.
Read more here
Manchester United have reportedly entered the race for Eintracht Frankfurt striker Hugo Ekitike.
Frankfurt are said to be demanding around £85million (€100m) for Ekitike, who has four years left on his deal.
Tom Cleverley is reportedly set to become the new Plymouth Argyle manager.
The Telegraph report that Cleverley is in advanced talks to take over at the League One club.
The former Manchester United midfielder was sacked by Watford last month.
Matheus Cunha is the first signing of a huge summer at Manchester United.

Everyone knows how important recruitment will be at Old Trafford over the next few months as the Reds look to recover from their lowest-ever Premier League finish. The absence of European football at M16 will only make that task harder.

One man who has followed Cunha's career closely in England is Wolves correspondent for the Express and Star, Liam Keen. He explains why United may have been so eager to wrap up a £62.5million deal for the Brazilian.
Read the full piece here
RB Leipzig striker Benjamin Sesko has been advised to turn down a move to Saudi Arabia after previous interest from Manchester United.
Read more here
Manchester United continue to be linked with a summer move for Sporting's Viktor Gyokeres in their search for a new striker.

The Sweden international has emerged as one of Europe's top strikers in recent years, with a remarkable record of 97 goals in 102 matches since his move from Coventry City to Liga Portugal in July 2023.

And the bookmakers at Bet365. have United as firm favourites to sign the striker at odds of 2/7. Premier League rivals Arsenal are seen as second favourites at 7/1 with the Gunners appearing to be focusing more on RB Leipzig's Benjamin Sesko instead.
Read more here

The big news this afternoon is that Matheus Cunha has formally put pen-to-paper on his transfer to United from Wolves for a £62.5million fee. It wasn't exactly a secret at Old Trafford and beyond, it must be said, but positive sings this summer already for Ruben Amorim and key figures behind-the-scenes.
Read the full story here >>>
Manchester United still remain in the fight for Victor Osimhen who is looking for a move to the Premier League.

Transfer expert Graeme Bailey told United in Focus: "We’ve known about United and Osimhen for months, and it is genuine interest. United have known his wage demands and that he is prioritising a move to England for months; he has always wanted a Premier League move.

"I understand after talking with a source close to the player that we can confirm Osimhen is not basing his decision on money, if he were, he would have accepted the Saudi offer. He does, however, believe he is one of the best strikers in world football and wants to be paid as such, which doesn’t mean he will be demanding Saudi money from United.
"He knows United are an option and he wants to come to England. Chelsea is not an option; however, I am told not to rule out Liverpool.

"While not being concerned about Champions League football, he is not going to want to come and never play Champions League. United will have sold him the project with Bruno Fernandes staying, Cunha and Mbeumo joining."

headline: Manchester United 'handed Bryan Mbeumo transfer twist' after announcement made
body: Manchester United are reportedly having to come to terms with the news that Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo may consider Tottenham Hotspur a viable option when the transfer window reopens.

It is thought that now his old manager is at the club, Tottenham is a more lucrative proposition for Mbeumo than it once was. This report will come as a shock for the Reds after they had been confident of signing the predominantly right-sided winger this summer.

However, negotiations remained ongoing and United felt they had received enough reassurance from Mbeumo that Old Trafford was his preferred destination. The Sky report claims that Tottenham's interest remains in its infancy, with initial enquiries having been made about the forward's availability.

Should United now miss out on Mbeumo, the start to their transfer window suddenly becomes a little more bleak as this would be the second high profile target they have missed out. Liam Delap was seen as a priority for the Reds at the beginning of the summer but he would eventually choose to join Chelsea instead.

headline: Bryan Mbeumo could be about to teach Man United the true cost of Europa League heartbreak
body: On the day in which Matheus Cunha proudly spoke about the lure of joining Manchester United regardless of the club's current circumstances, the Reds' next priority target may be about to ruin the feel-good factor.

While there could be a desire for Mbeumo to stick with a manager that he knows well, that argument feels flimsy at best. Had the forward wanted to stick with Frank, he could have done this summer by not entering discussions with the Reds.

Instead, Mbeumo decided to negotiate with Ruben Amorim's men as he wanted the new challenge - all of this happened before knowing that Frank was moving to Spurs. So it could be a reason why Spurs now looks intriguing but perhaps there is something more concerning happening here.

Tottenham were not in the conversation for Mbeumo prior to hiring Frank so as far as the Cameroonian was concerned, United were his only option. Now that Spurs are on the table, perhaps they look more enticing because they are in the Champions League and the Reds are not.

When a player is picking their next move, they are always looking at how their career can progress from its current position and if Mbeumo's head is turned by Tottenham, it could be more down to their position in Europe than Frank's arrival. Arguably, United only have a miniscule more pull than Brentford at present due to the size of the club but it is certainly not because they are performing better on the pitch.
If he was basing his decision on that, he would not be leaving the Bees. The concern for United is whether this will soon become a pattern for the Reds.
They are interested in a talent, a club in the Champions League come in, United miss out. It happened with Delap, it could happen with Mbeumo, what's to stop it happening again and again this summer.

If it had not already set in how disappointing the defeat to Spurs was in the Europa League final, it shall soon feel very real for the Reds if they keep being beaten to signings by clubs in Europe. Not every player is going to be like Cunha and perhaps that is something Amorim and co. need to accept.

headline: Man United dream starting XI after £170.5m summer transfer deals
body: Manchester United are entering the 2025/26 season with a point to prove and the pressure firmly on the shoulders of their manager Ruben Amorim.

To do that, he will have to be proactive in the summer transfer window and with the market reopening on Monday, it is expected the Reds will be busy before the start of pre-season. Ahead of the second part of the summer, MEN Sport has asked Google's AI software Gemini to name United's dream starting XI for the Premier League next season.

According to the technology, United are realistically just two more transfers away from completing their dream scenario next season. Gemini included Matheus Cunha in the starting line-up following his £62.5m move from Wolverhampton Wanderers and he is placed alongside captain Bruno Fernandes in attacking midfield.

Sporting's Viktor Gyokeres is deemed to be the next high-profile transfer that United should be looking to make amid a whirlwind summer that he is having. Both the Reds and Arsenal are thought to be leading the way for the Swede with the Lisbon club reportedly under fire from Gyokeres for quoting his asking price at £68m.

It is believed that the former Coventry City man was under the impression that he would be offered out for £51m this summer, something Sporting deny. With that move complicated, Gemini suggests that United could look at Napoli's Victor Osimhen as an alternative.

His release clause is understood to be at a reasonable £63m with the striker having already rejected a move to Al Hilal this summer. The final new addition that AI believes United should make is in goal, with Aston Villa's Emiliano Martinez named as the starting shot stopper.

The Argentine looked as though he bid farewell to the West Midlands following the final home game of the season against Tottenham Hotspur. He has been tight-lipped about his future since then and it is believed Villa would be looking for £40m if they were to allow their first-choice 'keeper to leave.
United have been credited with interest as they look at potential options to provide competition to Andre Onana. Atletico Madrid and Barcelona are also believed to be keen on Martinez.

Elsewhere, the dream starting line-up for United is made up of players who are already at the club. The only player who will not make the opening fixture for definite is Lisandro Martinez as he continues his recovery from a cruciate ligament injury.
He should be back towards the end of this year. There is also a new role for Amad to make room for Cunha as he is picked by Gemini to start at right wing-back.

There is no place for Brentford's Bryan Mbeumo either, despite United prioritising his signature. Gemini acknowledged that Mbeumo is likely to join United but perhaps see him at this stage as a strong player to come off the bench.

headline: Manchester United can repeat transfer victory over Liverpool with £51m deal
body: Manchester United could be given the chance to beat Liverpool in yet another transfer battle this summer.

United have already completed the signing of Matheus Cunha from Wolves to kickstart their summer transfer business. A deal worth £62.5million was agreed earlier in the summer, and now rumours are swirling about the business that United may have lined up next.

Portuguese newspaper O Jogo has reported that United have joined the race to sign Sporting Lisbon defender Goncalo Inacio. The report claims that United will compete with both Liverpool and Newcastle for the signing of Inacio this summer.
Inacio recently starred for Portugal as he helped guide his country to victory in the final of the Nations League.
Now the centre-back, who is reported to have a €60million (£51million) release clause in his contract at Sporting, could be a target for United this summer.
It was only 12 months ago that United and Liverpool were also in the race to sign a centre-back.
United won that battle when they completed the signing of Leny Yoro from Lille, a saga that also saw Real Madrid express an interest in the defender.
Inacio is under contract at Sporting until 2027 and has been linked with a move away from the Primeira Liga outfit for the last couple of years.
Inacio is not the only member of the Sporting squad to be mentioned as a target for United this summer, either.

Viktor Gyokeres is also reportedly a player of interest to United as the second phase of the summer transfer window approaches. United will be able to resume their transfer business when the window reopens on Monday.

headline: Manchester United need four sales to seal dream transfers
body: The transfer window will reopen again on Monday, meaning it will soon be time for Manchester United to step up their efforts in the seller's market.

United enjoyed a very encouraging start to the summer prior to the window temporarily closing on Tuesday, wrapping up the signing of Matheus Cunha from Wolves and identifying Brentford ace Bryan Mbeumo as their next target.

Despite seeing an opening offer worth £55million turned down for the Bees attacker, United have remained in talks with the Londoners and they are expected to lodge a new and improved bid once the window reopens.
It is believed Brentford are holding out for similar fee to the £62.5m United paid Wolves to sign Cunha, although the latter had a release clause in his contract at Molineux.

Nevertheless, Brentford are entitled to value Mbeumo at somewhere in the region of £60m on the back of a 20-goal season in the Premier League. However, if United press ahead with their pursuit of Mbeumo, make a breakthrough and sign him for a fee in the region of £60m, further incomings will then be fully dependent on outgoings.
United are unable to turn to a bottomless pit this summer and in addition to trying to sign Mbeumo, United also plan to sign a striker, a midfielder and a goalkeeper.
Fortunately, United have a crop of players they are actively looking to sell this summer, and a handful of them are big-name players, meaning they could be recipient of some handsome fees.
United's success rate in the seller's market has gradually improved under Ineos, but there is still a long way to go in their attempts to master the art of two-way recruitment.

United have identified Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho and Antony as priority sales after spending time out on loan in 2024/25. None of them feature in Ruben Amorim's plans and the club has no plans to reintegrate them into the squad this summer.

It is understood United value Rashford at £40m and Antony, who has created a market for himself after impressing on loan at Real Betis in the second half of the season, should be available for £32.5m.

United would have banked up to £25m from Chelsea for Sancho had they not backed out of their obligation to sign him permanently. It is expected that he will be available for somewhere in the region of £20m.

If United successfully offload those three at the aforementioned valuations, they will bank £92.5m, and that figure could go a long way towards funding the addition of a striker, which remains a top priority.

Although Rashford, Sancho and Antony have been identified as priority sales to bring in funds, Alejandro Garnacho is another player increasingly likely to move on. He has been informed he will be allowed to leave Old Trafford if the club receives an acceptable offer.

Napoli saw a £40m bid turned down for the Argentine back in January after it failed to meet United's valuation. Garnacho is a player with enormous potential and should be valued at a base price of £50m.
The prospect of adding that figure or more to the kitty would go a long way towards helping United achieve their ambitions this summer.

They have made an excellent start to the off-season by signing Cunha and putting the wheels in motion in an attempt to sign Mbeumo, but they need more than just two attackers. Without overseeing a crop of high-profile sales, however, they will be unable to do an awful lot more.

headline: Hugo Ekitike to Man United transfer would unlock 'exciting' first summer signing
body: Manchester United signing Hugo Ekitike ahead of Chelsea and Liverpool this summer transfer window would move Ruben Amorim closer to having a completely new-look front line next season.

Matheus Cunha, after completing a transfer from Wolverhampton Wanderers on Thursday, confirmed the first step of that overhaul. United director of football Jason Wilcox describes the Brazil international as "one of the most exciting and productive forwards in England".
He "proved his ability to succeed in the Premier League" at Wolves, notably at Old Trafford in April. However, he is not a centre-forward, playing best as a second striker behind a focal point.
Jorgen Strand Larsen was that for him last season, holding up play with impressive control and touch at 6ft 4in. Ekitike, in comparison, is of similar stature, at an inch shorter.

The latter, however, is heralded for attacking crosses, cutting inside from the left channel and running into space behind defences akin to Alexander Isak. While there may not be as many opportunities for the latter at United as playing for Eintracht Frankfurt, the other two tendencies bode well for playing in the Premier League.

Being clocked as one of the quickest players in the Bundesliga last season can only help an often slow-looking United forward line. A dozen assists across all competitions last term also hint at a developing ability to link play.

That is what Cunha is due to bring, but complementing the forward like Strand Larsen would be a bonus for Ekitike, as well as being more of a threat in front of goal, scoring 22 times in his first full season for Eintracht. Cunha enjoyed the best season of his career while playing with the big Norwegian, who likewise had his second-best goalscoring campaign.

Ekitike, meanwhile, combined with Omar Marmoush for the first half of last season. Nine of his assists and 14 goals came after the latter's transfer to Manchester City, showcasing an enhanced ability to provide for teammates when leading the line.

Cunha and Marmoush are comparable players, with no players across Europe's top five leagues scoring more from outside the penalty area last season. Their five strikes match Bruno Fernandes, Federico Valverde, Lamine Yamal and Kylian Mbappe.

The former, likely being in a more withdrawn role next season, suggests those numbers could drop. Cunha coming in ahead of the United captain suggests he can make up for any reduced productivity from range.

headline: Manchester United have fresh transfer deadline as Bryan Mbeumo wait continues
body: Manchester United must play a waiting game with the signing of Bryan Mbeumo.

The Reds are closing in on a deal for the forward, who has indicated he wants to move to Old Trafford. But Brentford rejected an initial United bid totalling £55million and negotiations remain ongoing.
The transfer window reopens on Monday, following an initial 10-day period at the start of the month where deals were permitted ahead of the start of the Club World Cup in America.
United wrapped up a move for Matheus Cunha in that initial window after activating his £62.5million release clause at Wolves and made progress on the Mbeumo deal.
The second window will stay open until September 1, shutting at the earlier time of 7pm, but United will want their new recruits in the building long before then.
Indeed, the Reds will aim to conduct the majority of their business this month, ahead of Ruben Amorim's squad returning for pre-season training in the first week of July.

Having new signings in the building ahead of time will allow Amorim the maximum opportunity to work with the players as United aim to improve on a wretched 2024-25 Premier League season. The Reds finished a lowly 15th in the top flight and defeat in the Europa League final ended any hopes of European football.

United will therefore have a lighter match schedule next term, which will allow Amorim more time to implement his methods. And doing so this summer with the new arrivals in place ahead of what will be his first full season in charge, could prove invaluable.
The United boss has spoken before of the importance of having time with his squad, something that was in short supply last term amid a relentless fixture schedule.

"We have more time to train, two days in a row, to train with the team," Amorim said ahead of facing Liverpool in January, a game which they drew 2-2 and produced one of their better Premier League performances under the Portuguese head coach.
"I think that can help us given the environment, it's a difficult moment because we are losing too many matches. We are going to face the best team this year.
"With training, we feel more the team, we prepare more the team and we want to improve the performance compared to the last game."

headline: How to buy new 2025/26 Manchester United Adidas home kit
body: Manchester United have unveiled their new home kit for the 2025/26 and it is available to purchase.
As per United tradition, the new home shirt is predominantly red and the collar and sleeve cuffs are black with a white trim. The shirt also features a V-neck collar.
There is also an abstract sleeve graphic in different shades of red to showcase the various elements of the pitch, stands and tunnel at Old Trafford.
United have also confirmed there is a 'Theatre of Dreams' sign-off on the back of the collar in a nod to Old Trafford. The Snapdragon logo is also the main shirt sponsor once again.
The new home strip is already available to buy online now via the United Store and Fanatics. Prices start at £80 for adults and £60 for juniors.
Manchester United have launched their new home kit for the 2025/26 season with an Adidas shirt paying tribute to Old Trafford.
Fans can order their Men's, Women's and Kid's shirt today.

On the design of the new home strip, Senior design director at Adidas, Jurgen Rank, said: "The colour red is fundamental to the club's DNA. There have been many different expressions of it over the years and, for this season, we wanted to do something a little different, using the sleeves as a canvas.
"The abstract graphic stays true to the club's DNA while providing an innovative look and feel to an otherwise classy and classic jersey."
The lightweight shirt features the latest in adidas technology, which United say has been created in close collaboration with the players, throughout the development process.
In addition to the shirt being of traditional United red, the kit launch has revealed the shorts will be white and the socks black. The shorts feature a black trim.

headline: Mason Mount sends perfect two-word message as Man United transfer completed
body: Mason Mount has taken to social media to wish Matheus Cunha well after he completed a move to Manchester United.
Just days after the Premier League season finished, United moved quickly to sign the Brazilian from Wolverhampton Wanderers by triggering the £62.5m release clause in his contract.
The 26-year-old was one of the standout performers this season, scoring 15 goals and providing six assists to help the Midlands outfit to a 16th-place finish in the Premier League.
On Thursday afternoon, United confirmed that all the paperwork for the deal had been completed and the forward had penned a five-year deal at Old Trafford.
Shortly after that announcement, Mount, who made the move to United from Chelsea two years ago, shared a snap of Cunha signing his contract on Instagram with the caption: "Welcome brother!"

Speaking as a Man United player for the first time, Cunha said: "It is hard to put into words my feelings about becoming a Manchester United player. Ever since I was a child in Brazil watching Premier League games on TV at my grandmother’s house, United was my favourite English team and I dreamed of wearing the red shirt.
"I want to thank my family and everyone who has helped me make that dream a reality.

“I can’t wait for the start of pre-season to get to know my team-mates and prepare for the season ahead. All my focus is now on working hard to become a valuable part of the team, and helping get this club back to the top.”
United's director of football, Jason Wilcox, added: “Bringing in Matheus was one of our main priorities for this summer, so we are delighted to have completed his signing so early in the window.

"He has proved his ability to succeed in the Premier League as one of the most exciting and productive forwards in England during his time at Wolves, and, before that, in Spain and Germany. He has all the qualities we are looking for as we seek to build a strong, dynamic and entertaining team capable of challenging for the biggest honours.”

headline: Manchester United can repeat Ayden Heaven and Chido Obi trick with latest signing
body: Manchester United are closing in on the signing of highly-rated Southampton youngster Harley Emsden-James to continue a recent transfer trend.

The 16-year-old centre-back is poised to make the switch to Old Trafford this summer after the two clubs agreed a compensation package. A report by the Daily Echo has claimed the fee will be a 'minimum of £1million'.
It is understood Jason Wilcox - United's director of football - played a key role in getting the deal in place. Wilcox worked at St Mary's before moving to Old Trafford last year.

United have developed a habit for signing some of the country's hottest prospects since Ineos took control of football operations last year, with the club's recruitment strategy improving for the better under their stewardship.
Hungry to sign young players with potential before they have announced themselves to the wider world, United are attempting to swoop for young talent in low-risk, high-reward deals.
The Reds did that on at least three occasions during the 2024/25 campaign, signing midfielder Sekou Kone from Malian club Guidars FC before swooping for Arsenal duo Chido Obi and Ayden Heaven.

Obi and Heaven have already made their first-team debuts at Old Trafford and the latter is already in the conversation to be a regular starter at centre-back next season. Obi will also be keen for more opportunities after impressing in a handful of cameo outings and scoring twice against Hong Kong on the post-season tour.
Obi joined United after he turned down the offer of a new deal at Arsenal and he signed his first professional contract at Old Trafford after celebrating his 17th birthday in November.
Heaven was signed for a minimal fee in the January transfer window and was considered as a first-team signing despite only making one senior appearance during his time at Arsenal.

United have high hopes for both of them and they will each for pushing for an increase in first-team minutes in 2025/26. If they are successful in their efforts, United's low-risk, high-reward transfer strategy will be fully vindicated.

headline: Manchester United new home kit for 2025/2026 season revealed
body: Manchester United have revealed their new home shirt for the 2025/2026 season.
The kit is predominantly red and the collar and sleeve cuffs are black with white trim.

The Snapdragon logo is again front and centre on the shirt. Qualcomm Technologies has a £60million per season sponsorship deal at Old Trafford and had their brand Snapdragon on the front of shirts for the first time last season.
The last time a United home shirt had a bespoke sleeve print was their 1996/98 home shirt, so the new shirt for the 25/26 campaign has a retro feel and fans will be hoping it brings success.
White shorts and black socks complete the kit, although black shorts and white socks will be available.
Manchester United have launched their new home kit for the 2025/26 season with an Adidas shirt paying tribute to Old Trafford.
Fans can order their Men's, Women's and Kid's shirt today.
Ruben Amorim will oversee his first full season in charge next term and must drastically improve his side after a 15th-place finish in the Premier League, which means there is no European football.
Amorim was appointed from Sporting Lisbon in November and didn't enjoy a new manager bounce, but he will strengthen in the summer transfer window and attempt to turn around the club's fortunes.
The signing of Matheus Cunha from Wolves was announced on the opening day of the window, and United are in talks to sign Bryan Mbeumo after their first bid was knocked back.
United would like to wrap up a deal for Mbeumo as soon as possible so he can report for the start of pre-season at Carrington in July.
The first pre-season fixture of the summer will be played against Leeds in Sweden on July 19, which will be the first sighting of the new home shirt.
The adult shirt costs £85 and a shirt for kids is priced at £60.

headline: Omar Berrada has given the green light to Manchester United's three priority sales
body: When the summer transfer window reopens next week, Manchester United will be determined to sanction a number of sales.
Having signed Matheus Cunha from Wolves for £62.5million and identified Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo as their next top target, United will soon have to make some sales.

After failing to secure Champions League qualification for next season, United's budget this summer is not as handsome as it would have been had they beaten Tottenham Hotspur in the Europa League final three weeks ago.

In addition to signing Cunha and attempting to lure Mbeumo, who is believed to be valued at around £60m, to Old Trafford, United also have aspirations of signing a striker, a midfielder and a goalkeeper. The addition of a specialist right wing-back has also not been ruled out.

If United are to achieve all of their objectives before the end of the summer, they are going to have to try and oversee plenty of outgoings. Although United are prepared to sell any player this summer, some are more likely to move on than others.
The trio, who all spent time away from Old Trafford on loan in 2024/25, are surplus to requirements and head coach Ruben Amorim has no plans to reintegrate them into his squad.
In truth, it is hard to see where they would fit into in his plans given his 3-4-2-1 system does not feature roles for natural wingers. In Amorim's system, width is provided by the wing-backs.

With that in mind, it makes perfect sense for United to cash-in on them amid chief executive Omar Berrada's comments about the club prioritising the benefit of the team over finances when making a decision on any outgoings.
"We need to be cautious and, and we need to try to make as many good decisions as we can in recruitment," said Berrada, speaking in March.
"And also when it comes to sales, we will do it purely on the basis of whether it helps improve the team or not, not for financial reasons."

In addition to wanting to offload Rashford, Sancho and Antony, United are also open to letting go of Alejandro Garnacho this summer. He was informed last month that he will be sold if an acceptable offer is submitted.
Napoli had a £40m bid rejected for the 20-year-old in January and it remains to be seen if they will submit a fresh offer. United are set to hold out for a higher fee this summer.

Like Rashford, Sancho and Antony, selling him would make sense given United now operate with a winger-less system. Furthermore, he would also command a hefty transfer fee that could go a long way towards potentially funding the addition of a striker or strengthening another priority position.

headline: Manchester United might have a secret weapon to help them seal Victor Osimhen transfer
body: After missing out on Liam Delap, it remains to be seen who Manchester United will turn to in their quest to strengthen the tip of their attack this summer.
United had installed Delap as their first-choice option after it emerged he was attainable via a £30million release clause.

After scoring a respectable 12 Premier League goals for relegated Ipswich Town, Delap attracted interest from a handful of clubs. However, it was Chelsea's project that appealed to him most and he recently made the switch to Stamford Bridge.
The good news for United is that plenty of time remains this summer to find an alternative goal-getter. Despite being temporarily closed, the window will reopen as soon as Monday.
Naturally, the rumour mill has been in full swing lately, linking United with just about every striker who has ever scored a goal. However, some names keep cropping up more than others.

Among them are Sporting Lisbon striker Viktor Gyokeres, Napoli ace Victor Osimhen and soon-to-be free agent Jonathan David, who will leave Lille at the end of this month after five years at the French club.
Each of them rank among the best strikers that are set to be attainable this summer, but who United could end up with come the end of the transfer window remains anybody's guess.

The club is currently focusing on trying to sign Bryan Mbeumo from Brentford, meaning incomings could slow until United oversee some outgoings. It is no secret that player sales will dictate what else United may be capable of this summer.
However, one way or another, United must sign a proven goalscorer before the window closes on September 1.
With a proven goalscorer required, United know they are going to have to loosen their purse strings. Established goalscorers are expensive and everyone wants one.

Over the last few years, few strikers have been as consistent in front of goal as Osimhen. The Nigeria international, who Napoli are actively looking to sell this summer, has scored 85 goals over the last three seasons, including 37 goals out on loan at Galatasaray in 2024/25.

Osimhen would be an excellent signing for United. He has a proven record in front of goal, is entering his prime at the age of 26 and he has already admitted he would love to play in the Premier League.
"I think playing in one of the top five leagues in the world (Serie A) is an amazing feeling for me," Osimhen said, speaking back in March 2023.
"A lot of people worldwide consider the Premier League as the best and the strongest league but now I'm in one of the best leagues in the world which is the Italian Serie A.
"I'm working so hard to make sure that I achieve my dream of playing in the Premier League someday but, like I said, it's a process and I just want to keep on this momentum and continue to do well."

Although it has not deterred Matheus Cunha from joining United and Mbeumo wanting to join him at Old Trafford, a lack of European football next season could hinder United's chances of attracting Osimhen. He has not gone a season without playing in Europe since 2018/19.
Recently the subject of interest from Saudi Arabian club Al-Hilal, Osimhen is also likely to command big wages and that could be an issue.
But what United do have is a crop of big-name players they want to sell, including Alejandro Garnacho. The Argentine has been informed he can leave if United receive an acceptable offer.

United rejected a £40m bid from Napoli for the 20-year-old in January and are expected to hold out for a higher fee this summer. Somewhere in the region of £50m-£60m would reflect a fair market value for the Argentine based on his potential.

Admired by Napoli and head coach Antonio Conte, it remains to be seen if the Serie A champions will make a fresh approach for Garnacho this summer. If they have retained their interest and show a strong desire to take him to Naples, Osimhen might creep into United's thoughts when negotiating.
Signing a striker of Osimhen's ilk and offloading Garnacho would be a win-win situation for everyone concerned.

headline: Manchester United have the green light to make major Bruno Fernandes change
body: Following the capture of Matheus Cunha and their ongoing pursuit of Bryan Mbeumo, Manchester United's attack is set to have a very different look to it next season.

United secured the services of Cunha on the opening day of the summer transfer window after triggering his £62.5million release clause and have now set their sights on trying to land Brentford star Mbeumo, who is keen on sealing a move to Old Trafford.

United had an opening offer for the Cameroonian turned down last week, understood to be worth £55m, but talks between the two clubs have remained ongoing and an improved is expected to be made once the transfer window reopens next week.

If the Reds extract Mbeumo from the Gtech Community Stadium, they will inherit a player who scored 20 goals in the 2024/25 Premier League campaign. Cunha has arrived at Old Trafford on the back of a 17-goal season.

With that said, both would occupy starting berths in M16, immediately forcing their way into Ruben Amorim's first-choice XI. Cunha is expected to operate from the left-sided No.10 role and Mbeumo from the right.

The latter predominantly plays as a right-winger at Brentford but often drifts inside, taking up central positions. His versatility means that he should easily adapt to operating in one of the two playmaker roles in Amorim's 3-4-2-1 system.

As a result of Cunha and Mbeumo potentially occupying those two positions, Bruno Fernandes and Amad, who often operated as the two No.10s in 2024/25, would have to be deployed elsewhere. Fortunately, both players are versatile enough to operate from different areas of the pitch.

Fernandes is comfortable operating as a No.8 and Amad is equally effective as a right wing-back. And if Fernandes is tasked with making the centre of midfield his permanent residence, he would be only too happy to do so, admitting just over a year ago that he imagined himself operating from a deeper position as his career progressed.

"In terms of passing, game organisation, defence, tactics," Fernandes said, speaking in March 2024. "I have a little thought in my head that I'm going to end my career further back, because everyone who started there and went to No.10 ended up retreating on the field at the end.

"It's a position I like, playing deeper, facing the game more. With the ball, it makes my game a lot easier because I have a broader view of the game and it is ideal for what we've talked about with the last pass, which can sometimes come from deeper on the pitch."

Fernandes proved on countless occasions in 2024/25, particularly this side of Christmas, that he is a more than capable operator from the centre of midfield. He enjoyed an excellent run of form between late-January and the March international break, scoring nine times.

If Fernandes is tasked with making one of the two No.8 positions his long-term role, United will have to ensure they find him a suitable midfield partner to compliment his qualities. Manuel Ugarte blew hot and cold in his first season at the club and doubts have been raised about his ability on the ball.
In addition to wanting Mbeumo and a striker, United also remain keen to sign a new midfielder. However, outgoings will dictate what it possible over the course of the summer.

headline: Man Utd ‘resume talks’ to seal £64m Osimhen swoop but have ‘not given up on’ Gyokeres
body: Man Utd have ‘resumed talks’ over a potential move for Napoli striker Victor Osimhen but Viktor Gyokeres is also still in the frame, according to reports.
The Red Devils are still recovering from a dreadful season under Ruben Amorim after the Portuguese head coach failed to improve on Erik ten Hag’s poor start to the campaign.
Amorim’s side will go down as the worst Man Utd team to have played in the Premier League with his 15th-placed outfit winning just 11 matches in 38 this term.
They also blew their ticket to Champions League qualification, which would have boosted their transfer budget, by losing 1-0 to Tottenham in the Europa League final last month.
Man Utd particularly struggled with scoring goals in the Premier League as Zirkzee and fellow striker Rasmus Hojlund came in for lots of criticism.
The strike duo only scored seven Premier League goals between them, although Zirkzee missed the final couple of months through injury.
READ: Transfer rumour power ranking: Man Utd to rival Liverpool, Chelsea; new Nunez link
Only four Premier League sides scored fewer goals than Man Utd in the 2024/25 campaign and now INEOS’ initial focus in the transfer market is improving their attack.
Matheus Cunha has already arrived at Old Trafford from Wolves in deal worth £62.5m, while Man Utd have also had a bid rejected for Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo.
Man City academy product Liam Delap had reportedly been their top centre-forward target before Chelsea beat them to the Ipswich Town striker’s signature.
There have also been rumours that Man Utd have made contact with Sporting CP over a potential move for Gyokeres with Arsenal also in the running for the striker.

But now French website Foot Mercato insist that Osimhen is emerging as an option again for Man Utd with the Nigeria international ‘looking for a new club’ still after he ‘failed to reach an agreement’ with Saudi Arabian side Al-Hilal, despite a ‘lavish offer’.
Turkish giants Galatasaray, where he spent last season on loan from Napoli, ‘still hopes to keep him’ but the 26-year-old ‘has resumed talks with’ Premier League side Man Utd.
The striker ‘had discussed with Manchester United at the beginning of May the conditions of a possible arrival at Old Trafford’.

And now ‘talks have resumed very recently under the conditions discussed a few weeks ago, namely a salary of €12 million for the player and compensation of €75 million including bonuses for Napoli, the club that owns the player’.
READ NEXT: Five Brentford stars reassigned to PL rivals amid Frank to Tottenham as Man Utd, Arsenal benefit
According to reports, Liverpool have held a ‘private’ meeting’ over signing a £63m striker, who has a ‘most likely destination’ this summer.
Man Utd are prepared to use Joshua Zirkzee in a swap deal to sign Victor Osimhen from Napoli in the summer transfer window, according to reports.
Victor Osimhen has rejected Saudi Arabian side Al Hilal, despite a €75million (£63.2m) package being agreed with Napoli, according to reports.
Saudi Arabian side Al Hilal have submitted an official offer to Napoli for striker Victor Osimhen, according to Fabrizio Romano.
Man Utd captain Bruno Fernandes holds the key to the Red Devils’ potential efforts to sign Victor Osimhen in the summer, according to reports.
It all felt a bit Liam Delap or bust for Man Utd, but they’re back to the drawing board and we’ve struggled to come up with these seven striker options.

headline: Tottenham ‘receive encouragement’ over Man Utd hijack with Mbeumo now ‘more intrigued’
body: Tottenham have ‘received encouragement’ over a possible transfer for Man Utd target Bryan Mbeumo after ‘initial discussions with Brentford’.
Man Utd are looking to sign another new forward after unveiling Matheus Cunha as a new signing at Old Trafford on Thursday.
Mbeumo has been the subject of interest from the Red Devils for a long time with journalist Ben Jacobs revealing yesterday that Ruben Amorim’s side are set to make a second formal bid “imminently”.
Jacobs told The United Stand: “There hasn’t been a formal second bid placed yet. But what is happening, is there are conversations around a new number, much closer to the Matheus Cunha valuation.

“And when Manchester United feel that not just that number, but the structure is competitive based on their feedback from Brentford – and all of those discussions are ongoing at the moment – the expectation, and quite imminently, is they will then put that formal second bid in with a higher percentage chance.
“Hopefully from Manchester United’s point of view, that will be accepted.”
READ: Transfer rumour power ranking: Man Utd to rival Liverpool, Chelsea; new Nunez link

‘Mbeumo is understood to be more intrigued by a move to Tottenham now that Thomas Frank has become their head coach. And Spurs have received encouragement about a potential deal now that the Dane has made the switch to North London.
‘Last week we reported Spurs had stepped up their interest in Semenyo prior to sacking Ange Postecoglou. Manchester United had a bid rejected for Mbeumo before Spurs started talks to hire Frank.

MORE ON TOTTENHAM FROM F365:
👉 Frank ‘demands’ Man Utd transfer hijack in style of deal which enraged Liverpool rival
👉 Tottenham want second Brentford regular for Thomas Frank after ‘closely tracking’ him
👉 Five Brentford stars reassigned to PL rivals amid Frank to Tottenham as Man Utd, Arsenal benefit
‘And we reported last week that United are expected to make another offer for the Cameroon star. United are also interested in Semenyo too.’
And former Man Utd chief scout Mick Brown – who is still well-connected in the Premier League – reckons Frank ‘could be a big pull for Mbeumo’ this summer.

Brown told Football Insider: “It’s going to be difficult to beat Man United to Mbeumo. United are well down the line on this move, and the player himself wishes to make that move to Old Trafford rather than other potential clubs.
“Thomas Frank could be a big pull for Mbeumo, but United are very optimistic that they’ll be able to land the Cameroon international.
“They’ve had one bid rejected and talks are ongoing with Brentford. They just need to reach a compromise over his fee and then that deal will get done.

“The other factor is that Spurs won’t be able to match United on wages they could offer. So Man United are still in the driving seat to get this done, despite suggestions that Tottenham could hijack their move.”
With Thomas Frank off to Spurs, we have jumped the gun on a possible Brentford exodus and reassigned five Bees stars to rival Premier League clubs…
Tottenham are reportedly among the sides who have been ‘closely tracking’ a Brentford midfielder, as Thomas Frank could look to take two Bees players with him.
Former Premier League manager Alan Pardew has told Manchester United that a forward who scored 20 goals last season “looks right” for them, and they are “desperate” for his services.
Tottenham Hotspur-bound Thomas Frank has been encouraged to make a “Manchester United hijack” his “first order of business” this summer.
According to reports, Tottenham Hotspur are ‘set to complete’ a deal to appoint Brentford boss Thomas Frank after ‘hitting an awkward roadblock’.
Man Utd are set to make a second “formal bid” for Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo “imminently” as Viktor Gyokeres pushes for a move, according to reports.

headline: The Famous F365 Friday Quiz: FIFA Club World Cup edition…
body: Everyone has FIFA Club World Cup fever and the only cure is the Famous F365 Friday Quiz: Identify the clubs these ex-Prem stars will represent in USA…
The FIFA Club World Cup kicks off this weekend. That exciting, isn’t it? Isn’t it?!
Thirty-two teams are in the United States to participate in Gianni Infantino’s wet dream, with Manchester City and Chelsea representing the Premier League. ‘
You will recognise plenty of players from having played in England earlier in their career.
We’ve got 20 of them. All you have to do is tell us which club they will be representing – begrudgingly, perhaps – at the CWC.
You’ll need a perfect score to beat Soutar…
If you enjoyed that and need more reasons to look busy, or you need to redeem yourself, we’ve got plenty more quizzes here. And our friends at Planet Football have even more.
If you’re quizzed out, don’t miss these…
Famous F365 Friday Quiz: FA Cup finals | Random 90s players | English league derbies
Missing Men: Liverpool | Arsenal | Chelsea | Man City | Man Utd | Spurs

headline: Transfer rumour power ranking: Man Utd to rival Liverpool, Chelsea; new Nunez link
body: Manchester United are in for an £85million striker, are they? Also, Darwin Nunez could have a choice to make…
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to becoming done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

19) 🆕 Bradley Barcola – PSG to Liverpool
Since Newcastle are selfishly refusing to sell them Alexander Isak, the PSG forward is said to be next on the Reds’ list.  Bayern Munich are also keen on Barcola.

18) 🔽 Mike Maignan – AC Milan to Chelsea
Chelsea are being weird here. They wanted Maignan in for the Club World Cup but refused to pay more than £10-12million, only just over half the price Milan want to sell the France no.1. Now the Blues can’t take him to USA, they don’t want him at all. That makes such little sense that it probably isn’t as dead as Chelsea want us to believe.

17) Victor Osimhen – Napoli to Manchester United
Osimhen apparently fancies a move to Old Trafford, presumably because he’s seen the salaries United have been dishing out in recent years. Napoli want around £70million, though they may take Joshua Zirkzee in part-exchange. This one doesn’t pass the sniff test, unless we get to late in the window with all parties in the same position they are now.

MORE ON THE SUMMER 2025 TRANSFER WINDOW
👉 Every Premier League transfer and release confirmed in the summer of 2025
👉 Twenty biggest transfers in the world in 2025 summer transfer window
👉 Wirtz next? The last five times every Premier League club broke transfer record

15) 🆕 Wilfried Ndidi – Leicester to Manchester United
The Nigeria midfielder has a £9million release clause and United see him as a good value squad addition to bolster their midfield options, especially if they sell Casemiro this summer. Which makes sense. Everton and the Saudis are also sniffing.

14) James Trafford – Burnley to Newcastle
Word is that Newcastle and Burnley are haggling over the price of a deal that Eddie Howe wanted to do a year ago, with the intention of Trafford and Nick Pope slugging it out for the No.1 spot. Which rarely ever works. Or at least that’s what Howe might tell Pope, but if this comes off, the current Toon keeper’s days are numbered. So Pope might be happy to hear that the two clubs are some way off an agreement with Burnley said to be asking for £40million.

13) 🆕 Oleksandr Zinchenko – Arsenal to AC Milan
Zinchenko has been surplus to requirements for some time and with a year remaining on his contract, Arsenal are motivated to sell. One problem: his fat salary is too rich for Milan’s taste. If they can overcome that obstacle, this definitely fits.

12) Antoine Semenyo – Bournemouth to Tottenham Hotspur
The Cherries reportedly want £70m, which feels unrealistic. A transfer still feels inevitable and Man United, Liverpool and Spurs have all been linked and Londoners are the favourites.

11) 🔼 Luis Diaz – Liverpool to Barcelona
Our reading on this: Barca want Diaz, who would be happy to move to the Nou Camp. Liverpool might be interested in a deal, but only on their terms. Which Barca won’t meet, and Diaz knows it so he won’t kick up a fuss – yet. If this is going to happen, someone needs to change tack. There is plenty of noise coming from Barca but nothing Liverpool can take to the bank.
MORE: Top 10 wingers available this summer features Arsenal, Liverpool targets and Man Utd outcast

10) 🆕 Darwin Nunez – Liverpool to Napoli
The rumours around Saudi interest remain but Napoli are now eyeing the Kop’s Captain Chaos. Will they pay the £60million-plus Liverpool apparently want? Only if they’re still p*ssed from their title celebrations. Saudi still seems  the Reds’ best hope of recouping as much of their £85million outlay as possible, but Nunez will have a say. Ambition, or his very own Scrooge McDuck money pit?

9) Benjamin Sesko – RB Leipzig to Arsenal
The Slovenia striker had overtaken Gyokeres as the favourite to fill the gaping chasm in the centre of Arsenal’s attack after much deliberation on the Gunners’ part. But perhaps they hadn’t accounted for how much of a slog it would be to negotiate with RB Leipzig, who are refusing to accept anything under their £70million valuation. As is their right. Especially when Al-Hilal seem keen to cough up if Sesko can be convinced to move to Saudi.

8) Viktor Gyokeres – Sporting to Manchester United
With Arsenal going cold on Gyokeres, there were plenty of reports that the Swede is open to a move to Old Trafford after all. Sporting say they haven’t received any offers and they also insist that reports of a gentleman’s agreement for him to leave for £59million are b*llocks. Which Gyokeres disputes. This could get messy.

7) Bryan Mbeumo – Brentford to Manchester United
Tottenham’s renewed interest threatened to scupper United’s hopes of landing Mbeumo but even the prospect of following Thomas Frank to Spurs isn’t deterring the forward from pursuing a move to Old Trafford. He’ll get his way ‘soon’, apparently.

6) Jamie Gittens – Borussia Dortmund to Chelsea
Chelsea’s improved offer has been swiftly rejected. But a third is expected despite the distraction of the Club World Cup for Chelsea and Dortmund. Gittens is keeping his phone on

5) Kepa Arrizabalaga – Chelsea to Arsenal
This one was moving quick, apparently, with Arsenal aware that the world’s most expensive goalkeeper will cost them just £5million. Interesting one, this. Kepa recovered some credibility on loan at Bournemouth last season and won’t be going to Arsenal just to play second fiddle to David Raya. Bring on the Gunners goalie wars!

4) Martin Zubimendi – Real Sociedad to Arsenal
This one got the ‘Here we go’ treatment over a month ago but then it all went a bit quiet. And then there was talk of Real Madrid sticking their nose in. Fear not, though, Gooners. Ornstein says it’s done.

3) Milos Kerkez – Bournemouth to Liverpool
Word last week was it’s happening. For around £40million. Which represents decent business for both sides. Things have gone a little quiet since while Liverpool pursue Wirtz but seemingly there is nothing or Reds to worry about here.

2) 🔼 Sverre Nypan – Rosenborg to Manchester City
Arsenal fancied their chances of landing the Norwegian wonderkid, and Villa were in talks in recent months. But City are in the mood for signings and it looks like they have agreed a £12.5million deal for the 18-year-old attacking midfielder.

1) 🔼 Florian Wirtz – Bayer Leverkusen to Liverpool
Liverpool will reportedly pay a British record £126.9m for Wirtz. That’s a lot of wonga. Is Rayan Cherki for a quarter of the price the better transfer? It might just be…
👉 Five reasons why Florian Wirtz may not actually be a good signing for Liverpool

headline: Man City leapfrog Chelsea in biggest summer spenders list but quadruple splurge still cheaper than Wirtz
body: Chelsea are bidding to be the world’s biggest spenders in the summer window for the fourth consecutive season, but Manchester City have overtaken them.
All fees and figures are taken from Transfermarkt. The 20 biggest deals of the summer are here.

10) Liverpool – £33.7m
They idle down on the list after the signing of Jeremie Frimpong and a new third-choice goalkeeper, but they will catapult to the top if they pull off the British record transfer of Florian Wirtz.

9) Burnley – £35.22m
Last season’s loans have been made permanent, with Bashir Humphreys the most expensive of the quartet. Now to persuade somebody not already in Burnley to sign for Burnley…

8) West Ham – £35.4m
Penny for the thoughts of Graham Potter, who inherited the ‘loan with obligation to buy’ deal that is Jean-Clair Todibo.
CHECK OUT: The F365 transfer rumour power ranking

7) Brighton – £41.5m
Perhaps in an effort to ensure Fabian Hurzeler has enough of an age gap over at least some of his squad, Brighton have spent a fair whack on three exciting teenagers from Sunderland, Daejeon Hana Citizen and Olympiacos.

6) Borussia Dortmund – £52.48m
They used the Club World Cup transfer window to bring in Jobe Bellingham and Yan Couto and they could add Jason Sancho.

5) Real Madrid – £58.5m
They have dropped £50m on Dean Huijsen and £8.5m on a few weeks of Trent Alexander-Arnold. Welcome to the big time, Xabi Alonso.

4) Juventus – £62.27m
Every penny has so far been spent on making loan signings permanent, with Nico Gonzalez their most expensive purchase.

3) Manchester United – £62.5m
They have completed the most expensive transfer of the summer so far with the capture of Wolves maverick Matheus Cunha, with Bryan Mbeumo likely to follow. We’re not sure where all this money is coming from…

2) Chelsea – £102.6m
They were the top spenders in the summers of 2024, 2023 and 2022 and will be up there in 2025 thanks to pre-arranged moves for Estevao, Dario Essugo, Mamadou Sarr and Kendry Paez. Throw in the £30m signing of Liam Delap and the Blues are already making very expensive waves.

1) Manchester City – £109.6m
That’s the price of a Rayan Ait-Nouri from Wolves, a Rayan Cherki from Lyon and a Tijanji Reijnders from AC Milan, and all of them feel like bargains. Pep Guardiola wanted Florian Wirtz but he will cost more on his own.
